title: Red sky in the morning really is a warning for rain, rain and more rain
text:
The fiery sunrise behind Saltburn pier and cliffs in Saltburn By The Sea, England, this morning (Picture: Getty)

Ever heard the old phrase red sky in the morning, shepherd’s warning?

It’s not a great omen for shepherds – or indeed anyone else if this week’s forecast is anything to go by.

Despite the stunning photographs of the deep red sunrise across the UK today, the Met Office has unfortunately confirmed the worst:

Today’s forecast… 🌧 🌧

🌧 🌧 🌧

🌧 🌧 🌧🌧 🌧🌧

🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧

🌧 🌧 🌧🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧 🌧 — Met Office (@metoffice) October 7, 2019

A yellow ‘danger to life’ warning of rain covering much of the UK on Sunday is no longer in place but it seems the wet weather is sticking around for a while yet.

Forecasters warn that the wet weather will be emphasised by wind going through the week.

Today the rain will spread east throughout the day, with Northern Ireland and Scotland brightening up later but still seeing some showers.

The rain will continue this evening and tonight over eastern, central and southern England and is not likely to stop until the early hours of Tuesday morning.

A red sky during sunrise at St Mary’s Lighthouse in Whitley Bay on the North East coast (Picture: PA)

It might look calm here but things are about to get wet and windy (Picture: Getty)

Pink skies were also spotted over London (Picture: @MPSonthewater)

Early risers made the most of the intense colours above their rooftops today (Picture: @semadivad)

Then throughout the day on Tuesday the Met Office predicts more of the same – with an added dose of blustery wind.

Forecasters predict the heaviest and most frequent showers will hit over the north, western Scotland and Northern Ireland.

The good news for the next few days? There is none – the rain continues.

Looks like that ‘shepherd’s warning’ thing really does ring true.
